normalization.tokenization_step: Home Â» Blog Â» AbereBot Returns as Escobar    A L L ,  B A N K I N G  T R O J A N ,  M A L W A R E ,  O S I N T    March 10, 2022    AbereBot  Returns as    Escobar    î¤    https://cyble.com/  https://cyble.com/blog/  https://cyble.com/uncategorized/  https://cyble.com/banking-trojan/  https://cyble.com/malware/  https://cyble.com/osint/  https://cyble.com/  https://cyble.com/      This Aberebot Banking Trojan Steals Data From  Google Authenticator And Taking Control Of  Compromised Device Screens. DuringÂ CybleâsÂ routine Open-Source Intelligence (OSINT) research, we came across aÂ Â Twitter post wherein  researchers mentioned a malware that has a name and icon similar to the legitimate anti-virus app,  McAfee.Â While analyzing the malware we observed that the package name of the malicious app was  com.escobar.pablo. Further research helped us identify this malware as a new variant of the popular banking  Trojan, Aberebot. Besides stealing sensitive information such as login credentials using phishing  overlays,Â Aberebot has also targeted customers ofÂ 140+Â banks and financial institutions across 18 countries. Cyble Research Labs has identified new features in this Aberebot variant, such as stealing data from Google  Authenticator and taking the control of compromised device screens using VNC, etc. Threat Actors (TAs) have  named the new variant as Escobar and published the feature details of the variant in a cybercrime forum, as  shown in the figure below. î¤    https://twitter.com/malwrhunterteam/status/1499390775775293454  https://cyble.com/2021/07/30/aberebot-on-the-rise-new-banking-trojan-targeting-users-through-phishing/      Figure 1- Darkweb Post About Escobar    Technical Analysis  APK Metadata Information    App Name: Â McAfee  Package Name: com.escobar.pablo  SHA256 Hash: a9d1561ed0d23a5473d68069337e2f8e7862f7b72b74251eb63ccc883ba9459f    Figure 2 shows the metadata information of an application. Figure 2 â App Metadata Information    The figure below shows the application icon and name displayed on the Android device. Figure 3 â App Icon and Name    Manifest Description    î¤        The malware requests users for 25 different permissions, of which it abuses 15. These dangerous permissions  are listed below. Permissions Description    READ_SMS Access SMSes from the victimâs device. RECEIVE_SMS Intercept SMSes received on the victimâs device    READ_CALL_LOG Access Call Logs    READ_CONTACTS Access phone contacts    READ_PHONE_STATE    Allows access to phone state, including the current cellular network  information, the phone number and the serial number of the phone, the status  of any ongoing calls, and a list of any Phone Accounts registered on the  device. RECORD_AUDIO  Allows the app to record audio with the microphone, which has the potential to  be misused by attackers    ACCESS_COARSE_LOCATION  Allows the app to get the approximate location of the device network sources  such as cell towers and Wi-Fi. ACCESS_FINE_LOCATION  Allows the deviceâs precise location to be detected by using the Global  Positioning System (GPS). SEND_SMS Allows an application to send SMS messages. CALL_PHONE  Allows an application to initiate a phone call without going through the Dialer  user interface for the user to confirm the call. WRITE_EXTERNAL_STORAGE Allows the app to write or delete files in the deviceâs external storage    READ_EXTERNAL_STORAGE Allows the app to read the contents of the deviceâs external storage    WRITE_SMS Allows the app to modify or delete SMSes    GET_ACCOUNTS Allows the app to get the list of accounts used by the phone    DISABLE_KEYGUARD Allows the app to disable the keylock and any associated password security    We observed a defined launcher activity in the malicious appâs manifest file, which loads the first screen of the  application, as shown in Figure 4. Figure 4 â Launcher Activity    Source Code Review  Our static analysis indicated that the malware steals sensitive data such as Contacts, SMSes, Call logs, and  device location. Besides recording calls and audio, the malware also deletes files, sends SMSes, makes calls,    î¤        and takes pictures using the camera, etc., based on the commands received from the C&C server. The code snippet shown below is used by the malware to access the contacts data such as phone numbers  and email addresses from the victimâs device, as shown in Figure 5. Figure 5 â Code to Collect Contacts Data    The code shown in Figure 6 is used by the malware to collect SMSes from the deviceâs inbox and upload them  to the C&C server. Figure 6 â Code to Collect Inbox SMSs    The malware collects incoming SMSes from the device and uploads them to the C&C server, as shown in Figure  7.    î¤        Figure 7 â Code for collecting Incoming SMSs    The code snippet shown below depicts the malwareâs ability to collect call logs from the device and upload it to  the C&C server. Figure 8 â Code to Collect Call Logs    Figure 9 showcases the code that illustrates the malwareâs ability to steal application key logs. Figure 9 â Code to steal key logs    In the below image, we see the code that is used by the malware to record audio from an infected device  based on the TAâs command. î¤        Figure 10 â Code to records Audio    On the TAâs command, the malware tries to steal Google authenticator codes, as shown below. Figure 11 â Steals Google Authenticator Code    The Escobar malware variant also uses VNC Viewer to remotely control the screens of an infected device, as  shown below. Figure 12 â Uses VNC Viewer to Control Device Screen    The malware can take pictures and also has the code to send text SMSes to a specific phone number or to all  the contacts saved in the victimâs device without the userâs knowledge. Refer to figure 13 for the code used by  the malware for this purpose. î¤        Figure 13 â Code to take Pictures and send SMSs  Acting to the commands given by the TAs C&C, the Escobar malware is capable of injecting URLs in the victimâs  device, as shown below. Figure 14 â Injects URLs    The malware can also steal media files from the victimâs device, as shown in the below code snippet. Figure 15 â Steals Files on the Device    The image below depicts the malwareâs ability to collect device location. Figure 16 â Code to Collects Device Location    Figure 17 showcases the code snippet used by the Escobar malware to monitor the victimâs device notifications. Figure 17 â Code for monitoring device notifications    The malware can also kill itself whenever it gets the commands from the C&C server. Figure 18 â Code to kill Itself    Below are the commands used by the TAs to control the infected device:    Command Description    Take Photo Capture images from the deviceâs camera    î¤        Send SMS Send SMS to a particular number    Send SMS to All Contacts Send SMS to all the contact numbers saved in the device    Inject a web page Inject a URL    Download File Download media files from the victim device    Kill Bot Delete itself    Uninstall an app Uninstall an application    Record Audio Record device audio    Get Google Authenticator Codes Steal Google Authenticator codes    Start VNC Control device screen    Conclusion  Banking threats are increasing with every passing day and growing in sophistication. Escobar is one such  example. The newly added features in the Escobar malware allow the malicious app to steal information from  the compromised device. According to our research, these types of malware are only distributed via sources  other than Google Play Store. As a result, practicing cyber hygiene across mobile devices and online banking  applications is a good way to prevent this malware from compromising your system. Our Recommendations  We have listed some essential cybersecurity best practices that create the first line of control against attackers. Download and install software only from official app stores like Google Play Store or the iOS App Store. Use a reputed anti-virus and internet security software package on your connected devices, such as PCs,  laptops, and mobile devices. Use strong passwords and enforce multi-factor authentication wherever possible. Enable biometric security features such as fingerprint or facial recognition for unlocking the mobile  device where possible. Be wary of opening any links received via SMS or emails delivered to your phone. Ensure that Google Play Protect is enabled on Android devices. Be careful while enabling any permissions. Keep your devices, operating systems, and applications updated. Regularly check the Mobile/Wi-Fi data usage of applications installed in mobile devices. Keep an eye on the alerts provided by Anti-viruses and Android OS and take necessary actions  accordingly. Disable Wi-Fi/Mobile data and remove SIM card â as in some cases, the malware can re-enable the  Mobile Data. Perform a factory reset. î¤        Remove the application in case a factory reset is not possible. Take a backup of personal media Files (excluding mobile applications) and perform a device reset. In case of a fraudulent transaction, immediately report it to the concerned bank. Banks and other financial entities should educate customers on safeguarding themselves from malware  attacks via telephone, SMSes, or emails.Â     MITRE ATT&CKÂ® Techniques  Tactic Technique ID Technique Name    Initial Access T1476 Deliver Malicious App via Other Mean.

Figure 3 â App Icon and Name Manifest Description î¤ The malware requests users for 25 different permissions, of which it abuses 15. These dangerous permissions are listed below. Permissions Description READ_SMS Access SMSes from the victimâs device. RECEIVE_SMS Intercept SMSes received on the victimâs device READ_CALL_LOG Access Call Logs READ_CONTACTS Access phone contacts READ_PHONE_STATE Allows access to phone state, including the current cellular network information, the phone number and the serial number of the phone, the status of any ongoing calls, and a list of any Phone Accounts registered on the device. RECORD_AUDIO Allows the app to record audio with the microphone, which has the potential to be misused by attackers ACCESS_COARSE_LOCATION Allows the app to get the approximate location of the device network sources such as cell towers and Wi-Fi. ACCESS_FINE_LOCATION Allows the deviceâs precise location to be detected by using the Global Positioning System (GPS). SEND_SMS Allows an application to send SMS messages. CALL_PHONE Allows an application to initiate a phone call without going through the Dialer user interface for the user to confirm the call. WRITE_EXTERNAL_STORAGE Allows the app to write or delete files in the deviceâs external storage READ_EXTERNAL_STORAGE Allows the app to read the contents of the deviceâs external storage WRITE_SMS Allows the app to modify or delete SMSes GET_ACCOUNTS Allows the app to get the list of accounts used by the phone DISABLE_KEYGUARD Allows the app to disable the keylock and any associated password security We observed a defined launcher activity in the malicious appâs manifest file, which loads the first screen of the application, as shown in Figure 4. The malware used the code snippet shown below to access the contacts data such as phone numbers and email addresses from the victimâs device, as shown in figure 5. Figure 5 â Code to Collect Contacts Data The malware used the code shown in Figure 6 to collect smses from the deviceâs inbox and upload them to the remote ip:*. Figure 6 â Code to Collect Inbox SMSs The malware collects incoming SMSes from the device and uploads them to the remote ip: *, as shown in Figure 7. î¤ Figure 7 â Code for collecting Incoming SMSs The code snippet shown below depicts the malwareâs ability to collect call logs from the device and upload it to the remote ip:*. Refer to figure 13 for the code used by the malware for this purpose. î¤ Figure 13 â Code to take Pictures and send SMSs Acting to the commands given by the TAs remote ip: *, the Escobar malware injects URLs in the victimâs device, as shown below. î¤ Figure 13 â Code to take Pictures and send SMSs Acting to the commands given by the TAs remote ip: *, the Escobar malware is capable of injecting URLs in the victimâs device, as shown below. As a result, practicing cyber hygiene across mobile devices and online banking applications is a good way to prevent this malware from compromising your system. Download and install software only from official app stores like Google Play Store or the iOS App Store. Use a reputed anti-virus and internet security software package on your connected devices, such as PCs, laptops, and mobile devices. Use strong passwords and enforce multi-factor authentication wherever possible. Enable biometric security features such as fingerprint or facial recognition for unlocking the mobile device where possible. Be wary of opening any links received via SMS or emails delivered to your phone. Ensure that Google Play Protect is enabled on Android devices. Be careful while enabling any permissions. Keep your devices, operating systems, and applications updated. Regularly check the Mobile/Wi-Fi data usage of applications installed in mobile devices. Keep an eye on the alerts provided by Anti-viruses and Android OS and take necessary actions accordingly. Disable Wi-Fi/Mobile data and remove SIM card â as in some cases , the malware can re-enable the Mobile Data. Perform a factory reset. î¤ Remove the application in case a factory reset is not possible. Take a backup of personal media Files (excluding mobile applications) and perform a device reset. In case of a fraudulent transaction, immediately report it to the concerned bank. Banks and other financial entities should educate customers on safeguarding themselves from malware attacks via telephone, SMSes, or emails. Figure 5 â Code to Collect Contacts Data The malware used the code shown in Figure 6 to collect smses from the deviceâs inbox and upload them to the remote ip:*. Figure 6 â Code to Collect Inbox SMSs The malware collects incoming SMSes from the device and uploads them to the remote ip: *, as shown in Figure 7. î¤ Figure 7 â Code for collecting Incoming SMSs The code snippet shown below depicts the malwareâs ability to collect call logs from the device and upload it to the remote ip:*. Figure 8 â Code to Collect Call Logs Figure 9 showcases the code that illustrates the malwareâs ability to steal application key logs. Figure 9 â Code to steal key logs In the below image, we see the code that is used by the malware to record audio from an infected device based on the TAâs command. î¤ Figure 10 â Code to records Audio On the TAâs command, the malware steal Google authenticator codes, as shown below. Figure 11 â Steals Google Authenticator Code The Escobar malware variant also uses VNC Viewer to remotely control the screens of an infected device, as shown below. Figure 12 â Uses VNC Viewer to Control Device Screen The malware can take pictures and also has the code to send text SMSes to a specific phone number or to all the contacts saved in the victimâs device without the userâs knowledge. Malware refer to figure 13 for the code used by the malware for this purpose. î¤ Figure 13 â Code to take Pictures and send SMSs Acting to the commands given by the TAs remote ip: *, the Escobar malware injects URLs in the victimâs device, as shown below. î¤ Figure 13 â Code to take Pictures and send SMSs Acting to the commands given by the TAs remote ip: *, the Escobar malware is capable of injecting URLs in the victimâs device, as shown below. Figure 14 â Injects URLs The malware can also steal media files from the victimâs device, as shown in the below code snippet. Figure 15 â Steals Files on the Device The image below depicts the malwareâs ability to collect device location. Figure 16 â Code to Collects Device Location Figure 17 showcases the code snippet used by the Escobar malware to monitor the victimâs device notifications. Figure 17 â Code for monitoring device notifications The malware can also kill itself whenever it gets the commands from the remote ip:*. Figure 18 â Code to kill Itself Below are the commands used by the TAs to control the infected device: Command Description Take Photo Capture images from the deviceâs camera î¤ Send SMS Send SMS to a particular number Send SMS to All Contacts Send SMS to all the contact numbers saved in the device Inject a web page Inject a URL Download File Download media files from the victim device Kill Bot Delete itself Uninstall an app Uninstall an application Record Audio Record device audio Get Google Authenticator Codes Steal Google Authenticator codes Start VNC Control device screen Conclusion Banking threats are increasing with every passing day and growing in sophistication. Escobar is one such example. The newly added features in the Escobar malware allow the malicious app to steal information from the compromised device. According to our research, these types of malware are only distributed via sources other than Google Play Store. As a result, practicing cyber hygiene across mobile devices and online banking applications is a good way to prevent this malware from compromising your system. Our Recommendations We have listed some essential cybersecurity best practices that create the first line of control against attackers. That download and install software only from official app stores like Google Play Store or the iOS App Store. That use a reputed anti-virus and internet security software package on your connected devices, such as PCs, laptops, and mobile devices. That use strong passwords and enforce multi-factor authentication wherever possible. That enable biometric security features such as fingerprint or facial recognition for unlocking the mobile device where possible. Security be wary of opening any links received via SMS or emails delivered to your phone. Security ensure that Google Play Protect is enabled on Android devices. Security be careful while enabling any permissions. Security keep your devices, operating systems, and applications updated. Regularly check the Mobile/Wi-Fi data usage of applications installed in mobile devices. Security keep an eye on the alerts provided by Anti-viruses and Android OS and take necessary actions accordingly. Disable Wi-Fi/Mobile data and remove SIM card â as in some cases , the malware can re-enable the Mobile Data. Malware perform a factory reset. î¤ Remove the application in case a factory reset is not possible. Reset take a backup of personal media Files (excluding mobile applications) and perform a device reset. In case of a fraudulent transaction, immediately report it to the concerned bank. Banks and other financial entities should educate customers on safeguarding themselves from malware attacks via telephone, SMSes, or emails. Â MITRE ATT&CKÂ® Techniques Tactic Technique ID Technique Name Initial Access T1476 Deliver Malicious App via Other Mean.
resolution.pr: Home Â » Blog Â » AbereBot Returns as Escobar A L L , B A N K I N G T R O J A N , M A L W A R E , O S I N T March 10, 2022 AbereBot Returns as Escobar î¤ https://cyble.com/ https://cyble.com/blog/ https://cyble.com/uncategorized/ https://cyble.com/banking-trojan/ https://cyble.com/malware/ https://cyble.com/osint/ https://cyble.com/ https://cyble.com/ This Aberebot Banking Trojan Steals Data From Google Authenticator And Taking Control Of Compromised Device Screens. DuringÂ CybleâsÂ routine Open-Source Intelligence (OSINT) research , we came across aÂ Â Twitter post wherein researchers mentioned a malware that has a name and icon similar to the legitimate anti-virus app, McAfee. Â While analyzing a malware that has a name and icon similar to the legitimate anti-virus app, McAfee we observed that the package name of the malicious app was com.escobar.pablo. Further research helped us identify a malware that has a name and icon similar to the legitimate anti-virus app, McAfee as a new variant of the popular banking Trojan, Aberebot. Besides stealing sensitive information such as login credentials using phishing overlays,Â Twitter Aberebot has also targeted customers ofÂ 140+Â banks and financial institutions across 18 countries. Cyble Research Labs has identified new features in this Aberebot variant, such as stealing data from Google Authenticator and taking the control of compromised device screens using VNC, etc. Threat Actors (TAs) have named the new variant as Escobar and published the feature details of the variant in a cybercrime forum, as shown in the figure below. î¤ https://twitter.com/malwrhunterteam/status/1499390775775293454 https://cyble.com/2021/07/30/aberebot-on-the-rise-new-banking-trojan-targeting-users-through-phishing/ Figure 1- Darkweb Post About Escobar Technical Analysis APK Metadata Information App Name: Â McAfee Package Name: com.escobar.pablo SHA256 Hash: a9d1561ed0d23a5473d68069337e2f8e7862f7b72b74251eb63ccc883ba9459f Figure 2 shows the metadata information of an application. Figure 2 â App Metadata Information The figure below shows the application icon and name displayed on the Android device. Figure 3 â App Icon and Name Manifest Description î¤ App Metadata Information requests users for 25 different permissions, of which App Metadata Information abuses 15. 25 different permissions, of which it abuses 15 are listed below. Permissions Description READ_SMS Access SMSes from the victimâs device. RECEIVE_SMS Intercept SMSes received on the victimâs device READ_CALL_LOG Access Call Logs READ_CONTACTS Access phone contacts READ_PHONE_STATE Allows access to phone state, including the current cellular network information, the phone number and the serial number of the phone, the status of any ongoing calls, and a list of any Phone Accounts registered on the Android device. RECORD_AUDIO Allows the app to record audio with the microphone, which has the potential to be misused by attackers ACCESS_COARSE_LOCATION Allows the app to get the approximate location of the device network sources such as cell towers and Wi-Fi. ACCESS_FINE_LOCATION Allows the deviceâs precise location to be detected by using the Global Positioning System (GPS). SEND_SMS Allows an application to send SMS messages. CALL_PHONE Allows an application to initiate a phone call without going through the Dialer user interface for the user to confirm the call. WRITE_EXTERNAL_STORAGE Allows the app to write or delete files in the deviceâs external storage READ_EXTERNAL_STORAGE Allows the app to read the contents of the deviceâs external storage WRITE_SMS Allows the app to modify or delete SMSes GET_ACCOUNTS Allows the app to get the list of accounts used by the phone DISABLE_KEYGUARD Allows the app to disable the keylock and any associated password security We observed a defined launcher activity in the malicious appâs manifest file, which loads the first screen of the application, as shown in Figure 4. Figure 4 â Launcher Activity Source Code Review Our static analysis indicated that the malware steals sensitive data such as Contacts, SMSes, Call logs, and device location. Besides recording calls and audio, the malware also deletes files, sends SMSes, makes calls, î¤ and takes pictures using the camera, etc., based on the commands received from the remote ip:*. the malware used the code snippet shown below to access the contacts data such as phone numbers and email addresses from the victimâs device, as shown in figure 5. Figure 5 â Code to Collect Contacts Data the malware used the code shown in Figure 6 to collect smses from the deviceâs inbox and upload the malware to the remote ip:*. Figure 6 â Code to Collect Inbox SMSs the malware collects incoming SMSes from the device and uploads the malware to the remote ip: *, as shown in Figure 7. î¤ Figure 7 â Code for collecting Incoming SMSs The code snippet shown below depicts the malwareâs ability to collect call logs from the device and upload the device to the remote ip:*. Figure 8 â Code to Collect Call Logs Figure 9 showcases the code that illustrates the malwareâs ability to steal application key logs. Figure 9 â Code to steal key logs In the below image, we see the code that is used by the malware to record audio from an infected device based on the TAâs command. î¤ Figure 10 â Code to records Audio On the TAâs command, the malware steal Google authenticator codes, as shown below. Figure 11 â Steals Google Authenticator Code The Escobar malware variant also uses VNC Viewer to remotely control the screens of an infected device, as shown below. Figure 12 â Uses VNC Viewer to Control Device Screen the malware can take pictures and also has the code to send text SMSes to a specific phone number or to all the contacts saved in the victimâs device without the userâs knowledge. Malware refer to figure 13 for the code used by the malware for this purpose. î¤ Figure 13 â Code to take Pictures and send SMSs Acting to the commands given by the TAs remote ip: *, the malware injects URLs in the victimâs device, as shown below. î¤ Figure 13 â Code to take Pictures and send SMSs Acting to the commands given by the TAs remote ip: *, the malware is capable of injecting URLs in the victimâs device, as shown below. Figure 14 â Injects URLs the malware can also steal media files from the victimâs device, as shown in the below code snippet. Figure 15 â Steals Files on the victimâs device The image below depicts the malwareâs ability to collect device location. Figure 16 â Code to Collects Device Location Figure 17 showcases the code snippet used by the Escobar malware to monitor the victimâs device notifications. Figure 17 â Code for monitoring device notifications the malware can also kill the malware whenever the malware gets the commands from the remote ip:*. Figure 18 â Code to kill the malware Below are the commands used by the TAs to control the infected device: Command Description Take Photo Capture images from the deviceâs camera î¤ Send SMS Send SMS to a particular number Send SMS to All Contacts Send SMS to all the contact numbers saved in the victimâs device Inject a web page Inject a URL Download File Download media files from the victimâs device Kill Bot Delete itself Uninstall an app Uninstall an an application Record Audio Record device audio Get Google Authenticator Codes Steal Google Authenticator codes Start VNC Control device screen Conclusion Banking threats are increasing with every passing day and growing in sophistication. Escobar is one such example. The newly added features in the Escobar malware allow the malicious app to steal information from the victimâs device. According to our research, these types of malware are only distributed via sources other than Google Play Store. As a result, practicing cyber hygiene across mobile devices and online banking applications is a good way to prevent this malware from compromising your system. our Recommendations our have listed some essential cybersecurity best practices that create the first line of control against attackers. That download and install software only from official app stores like Google Play Store or the iOS App Store. That use a reputed anti-virus and internet security software package on your connected devices, such as PCs, laptops, and mobile devices. That use strong passwords and enforce multi-factor authentication wherever possible. That enable biometric security features such as fingerprint or facial recognition for unlocking the mobile device where possible. Security be wary of opening any links received via SMS or emails delivered to your phone. Security ensure that Google Play Protect is enabled on Android devices. Security be careful while enabling any permissions. Security keep your devices, operating systems, and applications updated. Regularly check the Mobile/Wi-Fi data usage of applications installed in mobile devices. Security keep an eye on the alerts provided by Anti-viruses and Android OS and take necessary actions accordingly. Disable Wi-Fi/Mobile data and remove SIM card â as in some cases , App Metadata Information can re-enable the Mobile Data. Malware perform a factory reset. î¤ Remove the application in case Reset is not possible. Reset take a backup of personal media Files (excluding mobile applications) and perform a device reset. In case of a fraudulent transaction, immediately report a fraudulent transaction to the concerned bank. Banks and other financial entities should educate customers on safeguarding Banks and other financial entities from malware attacks via telephone, SMSes, or emails. That download and install software only from official app stores like Google Play Store or the iOS App Store.

Security keep your devices, operating systems, and applications updated.
Regularly check the Mobile/Wi-Fi data usage of applications installed in mobile devices.
Security keep an eye on the alerts provided by Anti-viruses and Android OS and take necessary actions accordingly.
Disable Wi-Fi/Mobile data and remove SIM card â as in some cases , App Metadata Information can re-enable the Mobile Data.
Malware perform a factory reset.
î¤ Remove the application in case Reset is not possible.
Reset take a backup of personal media Files (excluding mobile applications) and perform a device reset.
In case of a fraudulent transaction, immediately report a fraudulent transaction to the concerned bank.
Banks and other financial entities should educate customers on safeguarding Banks and other financial entities from malware attacks via telephone, SMSes, or emails.
Â MITRE ATT&CKÂ® Techniques Tactic Technique ID Technique Name Initial Access T1476 Deliver Malicious App via Other Mean.

word_verbosity.sent: Home Â » Blog Â » AbereBot Returns as Escobar A L L , B A N K I N G T R O J A N , M A L W A R E , O S I N T March 10, 2022 AbereBot Returns as Escobar î¤ https://cyble.com/ https://cyble.com/blog/ https://cyble.com/uncategorized/ https://cyble.com/banking-trojan/ https://cyble.com/malware/ https://cyble.com/osint/ https://cyble.com/ https://cyble.com/ This Aberebot Banking Trojan Steals Data From Google Authenticator And Taking Control Of Compromised Device Screens.

DuringÂ CybleâsÂ routine Open-Source Intelligence (OSINT) research , we came across aÂ Â Twitter post wherein researchers mentioned a malware that has a name and icon similar to the legitimate anti-virus app, McAfee.
Â While analyzing a malware that has a name and icon similar to the legitimate anti-virus app, McAfee we observed that the package name of the malicious app was com.escobar.pablo.
Further research helped us identify a malware that has a name and icon similar to the legitimate anti-virus app, McAfee as a new variant of the popular banking Trojan, Aberebot.
Besides stealing sensitive information such as login credentials using phishing overlays,Â Twitter Aberebot has also targeted customers ofÂ 140+Â banks and financial institutions across 18 countries.
Cyble Research Labs has identified new features in this Aberebot variant, such as stealing data from Google Authenticator and taking the control of compromised device screens using VNC, etc.
Threat Actors (TAs) have named the new variant as Escobar and published the feature details of the variant in a cybercrime forum, as shown in the figure below.

î¤ https://twitter.com/malwrhunterteam/status/1499390775775293454 https://cyble.com/2021/07/30/aberebot-on-the-rise-new-banking-trojan-targeting-users-through-phishing/ Figure 1- Darkweb Post About Escobar Technical Analysis APK Metadata Information App Name: Â McAfee Package Name: com.escobar.pablo SHA256 Hash: a9d1561ed0d23a5473d68069337e2f8e7862f7b72b74251eb63ccc883ba9459f Figure 2 shows the metadata information of an application.
Figure 2 â App Metadata Information The figure below shows the application icon and name displayed on the Android device.
Figure 3 â App Icon and Name Manifest Description î¤ App Metadata Information requests users for 25 different permissions, of which App Metadata Information abuses 15.
25 different permissions, of which it abuses 15 are listed below.
Permissions Description READ_SMS Access SMSes from the victimâs device.

RECEIVE_SMS Intercept SMSes received on the victimâs device READ_CALL_LOG Access Call Logs READ_CONTACTS Access phone contacts READ_PHONE_STATE Allows access to phone state, including the current cellular network information, the phone number and the serial number of the phone, the status of any ongoing calls, and a list of any Phone Accounts registered on the Android device.

RECORD_AUDIO Allows the app to record audio with the microphone, which has the potential to be misused by attackers ACCESS_COARSE_LOCATION Allows the app to get the approximate location of the device network sources such as cell towers and Wi-Fi.
ACCESS_FINE_LOCATION Allows the deviceâs precise location to be detected by using the Global Positioning System (GPS).
SEND_SMS Allows an application to send SMS messages.
CALL_PHONE Allows an application to initiate a phone call without going through the Dialer user interface for the user to confirm the call.

WRITE_EXTERNAL_STORAGE Allows the app to write or delete files in the deviceâs external storage READ_EXTERNAL_STORAGE Allows the app to read the contents of the deviceâs external storage WRITE_SMS Allows the app to modify or delete SMSes GET_ACCOUNTS Allows the app to get the list of accounts used by the phone DISABLE_KEYGUARD Allows the app to disable the keylock and any associated password security We observed a defined launcher activity in the malicious appâs manifest file, which loads the first screen of the application, as shown in Figure 4.
Figure 4 â Launcher Activity Source Code Review Our static analysis indicated that the malware steals sensitive data such as Contacts, SMSes, Call logs, and device location.
Besides recording calls and audio, the malware also deletes files, sends SMSes, makes calls, î¤ and takes pictures using the camera, etc., based on the commands received from the remote ip:*.
the malware used the code snippet shown below to access the contacts data such as phone numbers and email addresses from the victimâs device, as shown in figure 5.
Figure 5 â Code to Collect Contacts Data the malware used the code shown in Figure 6 to collect smses from the deviceâs inbox and upload the malware to the remote ip:*.

Figure 6 â Code to Collect Inbox SMSs the malware collects incoming SMSes from the device and uploads the malware to the remote ip: *, as shown in Figure 7. î¤ Figure 7 â Code for collecting Incoming SMSs The code snippet shown below depicts the malwareâs ability to collect call logs from the device and upload the device to the remote ip:*.
Figure 8 â Code to Collect Call Logs Figure 9 showcases the code that illustrates the malwareâs ability to steal application key logs.
Figure 9 â Code to steal key logs In the below image, we see the code that is used by the malware to record audio from an infected device based on the TAâs command.
î¤ Figure 10 â Code to records Audio On the TAâs command, the malware steal Google authenticator codes, as shown below.
Figure 11 â Steals Google Authenticator Code The Escobar malware variant also uses VNC Viewer to remotely control the screens of an infected device, as shown below.

Figure 12 â Uses VNC Viewer to Control Device Screen the malware can take pictures and also has the code to send text SMSes to a specific phone number or to all the contacts saved in the victimâs device without the userâs knowledge.
Malware refer to figure 13 for the code used by the malware for this purpose.
î¤ Figure 13 â Code to take Pictures and send SMSs Acting to the commands given by the TAs remote ip: *, the malware injects URLs in the victimâs device, as shown below.
î¤ Figure 13 â Code to take Pictures and send SMSs Acting to the commands given by the TAs remote ip: *, the malware is capable of injecting URLs in the victimâs device, as shown below.
Figure 14 â Injects URLs the malware can also steal media files from the victimâs device, as shown in the below code snippet.
Figure 15 â Steals Files on the victimâs device The image below depicts the malwareâs ability to collect device location.
Figure 16 â Code to Collects Device Location Figure 17 showcases the code snippet used by the Escobar malware to monitor the victimâs device notifications.
Figure 17 â Code for monitoring device notifications the malware can also kill the malware whenever the malware gets the commands from the remote ip:*.

Figure 18 â Code to kill the malware Below are the commands used by the TAs to control the infected device: Command Description Take Photo Capture images from the deviceâs camera î¤ Send SMS Send SMS to a particular number Send SMS to All Contacts Send SMS to all the contact numbers saved in the victimâs device Inject a web page Inject a URL Download File Download media files from the victimâs device Kill Bot Delete itself Uninstall an app Uninstall an an application Record Audio Record device audio Get Google Authenticator Codes Steal Google Authenticator codes Start VNC Control device screen Conclusion Banking threats are increasing with every passing day and growing in sophistication.
Escobar is one such example.
The newly added features in the Escobar malware allow the malicious app to steal information from the victimâs device.
According to our research, these types of malware are only distributed via sources other than Google Play Store.
As a result, practicing cyber hygiene across mobile devices and online banking applications is a good way to prevent this malware from compromising your system.
our Recommendations our have listed some essential cybersecurity best practices that create the first line of control against attackers.
That download and install software only from official app stores like Google Play Store or the iOS App Store.
That use a reputed anti-virus and internet security software package on your connected devices, such as PCs, laptops, and mobile devices.
That use strong passwords and enforce multi-factor authentication wherever possible.
That enable biometric security features such as fingerprint or facial recognition for unlocking the mobile device where possible.
Security be wary of opening any links received via SMS or emails delivered to your phone.
Security ensure that Google Play Protect is enabled on Android devices.
Security be careful while enabling any permissions.
Security keep your devices, operating systems, and applications updated.
Regularly check the Mobile/Wi-Fi data usage of applications installed in mobile devices.
Security keep an eye on the alerts provided by Anti-viruses and Android OS and take necessary actions accordingly.
Disable Wi-Fi/Mobile data and remove SIM card â as in some cases , App Metadata Information can re-enable the Mobile Data.
Malware perform a factory reset.
î¤ Remove the application in case Reset is not possible.
Reset take a backup of personal media Files (excluding mobile applications) and perform a device reset.
In case of a fraudulent transaction, immediately report a fraudulent transaction to the concerned bank.
Banks and other financial entities should educate customers on safeguarding Banks and other financial entities from malware attacks via telephone, SMSes, or emails.
Â MITRE ATT&CKÂ® Techniques Tactic Technique ID Technique Name Initial Access T1476 Deliver Malicious App via Other Mean.
